title: What is open data?
body:
Open data is data that anyone can access, use and share. Open data can transform interaction between governments, businesses and individuals. It has the power to improve services, grows economies and save our planet.

In this module we’ll look at:
  • What is open data?
  • What is data?
  • What makes data open?
  • Why do we need open data?

title: Discovering open data – in 2 minutes
body: The ODI’s David Tarrant explains what data is, what makes it open and why we need open data.

title: What is open data?
body:
Open data is data that anyone can access, use and share.

Open data becomes accessible by being available online.

Data becomes useable through being available in a common, understandable machine readable format.

Open data must be licenced. This license must permit the free usage of the data and allow users to transform, combine and share with others, even commercially.

title: From raw material to new information and knowledge
displayTitle: From raw material to new information and knowledge
body: Without data, we can’t build information.  And without information, there is no new knowledge.
instruction: Click the forward arrow to see more.Select the ‘+’ sign to explore further, then swipe the image to see more.

_items.title: Data
_items.body:
Data is the lowest level of raw material from which information and knowledge can be derived.

As an example, think of data as those locations, images, descriptions, reviews and prices that form the basis of information that can help people build a holiday.

_items.title: Information
_items.body:
Data becomes information when it is given a context.

Following on from the previous example, locations, images, descriptions and prices can all be related to a tourist attraction.

It is the collection and presentation of the data that forms information.

_graphic.alt: A graph of open licences across countries
_graphic.title: A graph of open licences across countries

_items.title: Knowledge
_items.body:
Knowledge is what is derived from the information, personalising it for your needs.

Knowledge is the process of turning information into choices.

Following on from the previous example, knowing that no one in your family likes theme parks will inform your decisions as to which locations to avoid and which would be more suitable for your purposes.

_graphic.alt: A map from a to b
_graphic.title: A map from a to b

title: What makes data open?
body:
Data is open if anyone can access, use and share it.
There are some simple things to consider when defining openness. Consider the following:

_items.title: Limitations
_items.body:
To be open there should be no limitations that prevents any particular use of the data.

A user should be free to use, modify, combine and share the data, even commercially.

_items.title: Cost
_items.body:
Even though data must be free to use, this does not mean that it must be free to access.

There is a cost in creating, maintaining and publishing useable data.

Ideally, any fee for data should be no more than the reasonable reproduction cost of the unit of data that is requested.

This reproduction cost tends to zero for many datasets.

Live data and big data can have ongoing cost related to reliable service provision.

_items.title: Reuse
_items.body:
Once the user has the data, they are free to use it, reuse it and redistribute it, even commercially.

Open data is measured by what it can be used for, not by how it is made available.

Aspects like format, structure and machine readability all make data more usable, and should all be carefully considered.

However these do not make the data more open.

title: Why do we need open data?
displayTitle: Why do we need open data?
body: Open data has the power to transform government, business and civil society.
instruction: Click the forward arrow to see more.Select the ‘+’ sign to explore further, then swipe the image to see more.

_items.title: Transform government
_items.body:
Open data increases the transparency of governments. It provides the evidence that public money is being well spent and policies are being implemented.

For example, according to leading Open Government activist David Eaves, in Canada in 2010, open data allowed citizens to save the government $3.2 billion in fraudulent charitable donations.
Take me to David Eaves article

In another example, according to Follow the Money, in Nigeria, the same process is used to ensure that public funds are used to implement the policies promised to the people.
Take me to Follow the Money

_items.title: Build new business opportunities
_items.body:
Open data is opening up new opportunities for businesses to connect to customers.

Transport for London have released open data that developers have used to build over 800 transport apps.
Take me to Transport for London

Thomson Reuters are using open data to better connect to existing customers in order to provide better services.
Take me to Thomson Reuters

The ODI startup program now has over 70 employees with income over £4m.
Take me to The ODI annual report

_items.title: Protect our planet
_items.body:
The web has become a core part of societal infrastructure and open data is the next key component of this infrastructure.

Open data provides an early warning system for environmental disasters.
Take me to the United Nations news centre

Open data is also helping consumers understand their personal impact on the environment and how to take responsibility for their effect.
Take me to Better Choices Better Deals report.

title: Are you ready for open data?
displayTitle: Are you ready for open data?
body: There are four helpful things to remember when thinking about opening your data for users, can you recall them?

_items.text: information that we sell to businesses.
data that anyone can access, use and share.
data that is visible on the web.

title: Open data - Veni, vidi, vici
body:
Open data is data that anyone can access, use and share.

Open data is the natural resource for the digital age and, unlike coal, timber or diamonds, it can be used by anyone and everyone at the same time.

Any restrictions imposed on the use of open data will limit its use in creating new value.

Open data can transform interaction between governments, businesses and individuals. It has the power to improve services, grow economies and save our planet.

In the next module, we look at how value is unlocked in open data.
